item.title: After Three Russians Are Charged, the Prospect of a Spy Swap Surfaces
item.description: The issue is surfacing after three men were accused by federal officials of working as covert agents for the Russian foreign intelligence agency.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER and KATE PASTOR

item.title: Outliving Horror for 70 Years and Never Forgetting
item.description: In 2005, about 1,500 survivors attended the 60th anniversary of the liberation of the death camps. This year, there were fewer than 300.
item.dc:creator: By JOANNA BERENDT
item.media:description: Dignitaries and survivors gathered Tuesday to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz and Birkenau concentration camps.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Report Sheds Light on Transgender Sex Workers in China
item.description: The report, “My Life Is Too Dark to See the Light,” draws on interviews with 70 people, most of whom left their rural hometowns to live in more liberal-minded cities, like Beijing and Shanghai, where they engage in sex work to make a living.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: Piao Piao found it hard to find a mainstream job in Beijing, so she became an entertainer in bars and a sex worker.

item.title: Leon Brittan Dies at 75; British Official in Leak Case
item.description: Mr. Brittan was a British politician who rose fast and far in the Margaret Thatcher government, only to see his career crash over a leaked letter in a dispute over a helicopter company.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Home Secretary Leon Brittan, who also held posts in the European Commission, talking to reporters in London in 1984.

item.title: Open Source: Egypt Condemns Western Outrage at Fatal Shooting of Protester
item.description: The Foreign Ministry expressed dismay that the killing of a female activist in Cairo had drawn widespread condemnation from the West.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Graphic images of Shaimaa al-Sabbagh, an Egyptian activist who was shot and killed at a peaceful rally in Cairo on Saturday, sowed outrage on social networks.

item.title: Russian Movie ‘Leviathan’ Gets Applause in Hollywood but Scorn at Home
item.description: The film has admirers and won a Golden Globe, but some Russian detractors want it banned and accuse its director of acting under Western orders.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexander Rodnyansky is one of the producers of “Leviathan,” an Academy Award contender.

item.title: Jordan Hostage Crisis May Hurt U.S. Ties
item.description: The Islamic State gave Jordan 24 hours or less to release a prisoner. If not, the militants said, they will kill not only a Japanese hostage, but also a captured Jordanian pilot
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: This still image taken from video released by the Islamic State's branch in Raqqa, Syria, shows the capture of Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, the Jordanian pilot shot down over Syria a month ago. The militant group has threatened to kill the pilot and a Japanese hostage within 24 hours.

item.title: Mexico Officially Declares Missing Students Dead
item.description: Four months after the students were abducted, Mexico’s attorney said general confessions and forensic evidence supported the theory that their bodies were incinerated near a garbage dump.
item.category: Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: In Reprieve to Obama, Senate Democrats Agree to Wait on Iran Sanctions
item.description: While the House of Representatives weighs whether to impose new sanctions on Tehran, the Iranian Parliament is working on a resolution of its own.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: The Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, was criticized for the stroll he took with Secretary of State John Kerry in Geneva on Jan. 14.

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Monarch Levels Rebound
item.description: The number of Monarch butterflies that reached wintering grounds in Mexico rebounded 69 percent this year from last year’s disastrous levels, the World Wildlife Fund said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: E.U. Sends Aid to East
item.description: The European Union delivered three planeloads of aid to eastern Ukraine on Tuesday, including blankets, tents, heaters and warm clothing.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Apple’s China Strategy Pays Off With Surge in Earnings
item.description: The introduction of a large-screen iPhone in China helped propel Apple’s profit to $18 billion and its revenue to nearly $75 billion.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN X. CHEN
item.media:description: An iPhone user in Shanghai. Apple has made a series of moves to compete more aggressively in China.

item.title: Pontassieve Journal: Life of Italian Nobility for Sale, Complete With Regulations and Taxes
item.description: Italy’s long heritage of inherited wealth and property has withered thanks to cuts in government subsidies and high maintenance costs, among other factors.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Chianti hills are visible from the Torre a Decima castle in Tuscany.

item.title: Fidel Castro Shares Views on Warming of Relations
item.description: In a letter, Mr. Castro wrote that he did not trust the politics of the United States, but added that this was not “a rejection of a peaceful solution to conflicts.”
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Botswana Doctor Is Named to Lead W.H.O. in Africa
item.description: The much-praised appointee, Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, promised to overhaul the regional office, which has faced criticism for its slow response to the Ebola crisis.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Lens Blog: Women Fighting for Their Land and Opportunity
item.description: In a hard-to-reach corner of Myanmar, Adriane Ohanesian went in search of the young female fighters of the Kachin Independence Army, which has waged a long civil war.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: Women changing into their uniforms in the room that 10 of them shared during their military training at the Third Brigade army base in Mai Ja Yang, Myanmar. While some of the women had joined out of their own interest in serving with the Kachin Independence Army, an equal number had been forcibly recruited, Adriane Ohanesian said. 2013.

item.title: Yahoo to Spin Off Its Stake in Alibaba
item.description: Shedding its 15 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce site turns the spotlight to Yahoo’s plans to revamp its core Internet advertising business.
item.dc:creator: By VINDU GOEL and MICHAEL. J. DE LA MERCED
item.media:description: Marissa Mayer, chief executive of Yahoo, in Davos this month.

item.title: Pakistan Criticizes India’s Inclusion in Nuclear Suppliers Group
item.description: The Pakistani national security adviser said Pakistan feared that India’s growing nuclear cooperation with the United States could harm deterrence efforts in South Asia.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Netanyahu Talk Stirs Backlash in Israeli Race
item.description: Critics are attacking Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who plans to address Congress before Israeli elections, for politicizing a key interest: curbing Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, at a Holocaust event on Tuesday, is scheduled to address Congress on Iran in March.

item.title: Firefight Kills 4 in Kashmir
item.description: A counterterrorism raid ended in the death of an Indian colonel.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
